title: How much will financial advice cost me?
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Oct 26, 2015, 13:26 GMT - UK Markets close in 3 hrs 4 mins How much will financial advice cost me? By Richard Evans | Telegraph – 2 hours 42 minutes ago 8.10 +0.11 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) can be hard to find out what an adviser will charge, as most do not state fees on their website, Which? says. Our table shows what you can expect to pay 
If you feel you need the help of a financial adviser to manage your money, the first thing you'll probably want to know is the cost. 
But it can be hard to discover how much an adviser charges without committing to a face-to-face meeting, according to Which?, the consumer lobby group. 
When Which? analysed the websites of 500 advisory firms it found that more than two thirds didn’t publish their fees and charges online, giving customers no advance indication of what they could be charged. 
• Seven ways to tell if your financial adviser is a shark 
It said just 2pc of the sites it looked at published "genuinely useful information" on fees, including a clear breakdown of charges. 
"Financial advisers are not being upfront with potential customers over what they could expect to be charged for advice," the group said. 
"We believe customers should have an indication of what they will pay before committing to meet advisers face-to-face, where they could face a full sales pitch." 
• How much should you pay for financial advice? 
Our table should help customers who feel left in the dark over advisers' charges. Compiled by unbiased.co.uk, an online directory of financial advisers, it shows typical charges for a variety of common advice needs. 
Advice scenario Typical (Shanghai: 600302.SS - news ) ('median') fee charged Investment Investment strategy for a £50,000 inheritance for a 50-year-old seeking medium-term growth £1,500 Retirement planning Advice on a £200-a-month pension contribution £580 " Advice on transferring a £30,000 pension with guaranteed annuity rates £900 " Advice on transferring a £100,000 pension with guaranteed annuity rates £2,000 " Specialist advice on 'defined benefit' (eg final salary) transfer £1,500 At retirement Converting a £30,000 pension fund into a lump sum and annuity £825 " Converting a £100,000 pension fund into a lump sum and annuity £1,750 " At-retirement advice on a £100,000 pension pot (client requires full advice) £2,000 " At-retirement advice on a £200,000 pension pot (client requires full advice) £2,500 There is a more detailed table at unbiased.co.uk/cost-of-advice
